conflicts.resolution: Distinguish by attachment location: Python docstrings appear as the first statement inside a function/class body (internal_first_line), while Julia docstrings appear immediately above the target definition (above_target). Context-aware parsing required.
conflicts.description: Both Python and Julia use triple-quoted strings for documentation, but with different attachment semantics. Python treats the string as an internal statement, while Julia treats it as a prefix annotation.

conflicts.resolution: Distinguish by nesting capability and delimiter variation: JavaScript uses /** */ (non-nestable), while D uses /++ +/ (nestable). D's plus-based delimiters allow safe nesting of documentation blocks. Check for plus vs asterisk after opening slash.
conflicts.description: JavaScript and D both use block comment syntax for documentation, but D's /++ +/ variant supports nesting while JavaScript's /** */ does not. D chose plus signs specifically to enable nested documentation without escaping.

conflicts.resolution: Both languages use identical /// syntax with identical attachment semantics. Disambiguation requires file extension or language context. Both support //! for module-level documentation. Treat as interchangeable for parsing purposes.
conflicts.description: Rust and Zig share the same line documentation comment syntax (///) with the same attachment rules. This is a deliberate design similarity rather than a conflict. Both languages also support //! for inner documentation (module-level).
